Rest API documentation master file, created by sphinx-quickstart on Thu May 30 2023. You can adapt this file completely to your liking, but it should at least contain the root toctree directive.

Welcome to Rest API’s documentation!¶

REST API main¶

main.healthchecker(db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
async main.root(request: Request)¶
async main.startup()¶

REST API repository Clients¶

async src.repository.clients.create_client(body: ClientModel, db: Session)¶

The create_client function creates a new client in the database.

Parameters:

  • body – ClientModel: Pass the data from the request body into a clientmodel object

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

A client object

async src.repository.clients.get_birthday(days: int, db: Session)¶

The get_birthday function takes in a number of days and a database session. It returns all clients whose birthday is within the next x days, where x is the number of days passed into the function.

Parameters:

  • days – int: Specify the number of days to look ahead for birthdays

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A list of clients with birthdays in the next x days

async src.repository.clients.get_client(client_id: int, db: Session)¶

The get_client function returns a client object from the database.

Parameters:

  • client_id – int: Specify the client id of the client we want to retrieve from our database

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A client object

async src.repository.clients.get_client_by_email(email: str, db: Session)¶

The get_client_by_email function takes in an email and a database session, and returns the client with that email. If no such client exists, it returns None.

Parameters:

  • email – str: Pass the email of the client to be retrieved from the database

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The client object with the given email

async src.repository.clients.get_client_by_phone(phone_number: str, db: Session)¶

The get_client_by_phone function takes a phone number and returns the client associated with that phone number.

Parameters:

  • phone_number – str: Filter the database query

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A client object that matches the phone number provided

async src.repository.clients.get_clients(limit: int, offset: int, db: Session)¶

The get_clients function returns a list of clients from the database.

Parameters:

  • limit – int: Limit the number of clients returned

  • offset – int: Determine how many clients to skip

  • db – Session: Pass in the database session

Returns:

A list of client objects

async src.repository.clients.remove_client(client_id: int, db: Session)¶

The remove_client function removes a client from the database.

Parameters:

  • client_id – int: Specify the client to be removed

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The client object that was deleted

async src.repository.clients.search_clients(data: str, db: Session)¶
The search_clients function searches the database for clients that match a given string.

The function takes in two parameters: data and db. Data is the string to be searched, and db is a Session object from SQLAlchemy.

Parameters:

  • data – str: Search for a string in the database

  • db – Session: Pass in the database session

Returns:

A list of client objects

async src.repository.clients.update_client(body: ClientModel, user_id: int, db: Session)¶

The update_client function updates a client’s information in the database.

Parameters:

  • body – ClientModel: Pass the data from the request body to this function

  • user_id – int: Get the client from the database

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

A clientmodel object

REST API repository Users¶

async src.repository.users.confirmed_email(email: str, db: Session) → None¶

The confirmed_email function takes in an email and a database session, and sets the confirmed field of the user with that email to True.

Parameters:

  • email – str: Pass the email of the user who is trying to confirm their account

  • db – Session: Pass in the database session

Returns:

Nothing

async src.repository.users.create_user(body: UserModel, db: Session) → User¶

The create_user function creates a new user in the database.

Parameters:

  • body – UserModel: Get the user’s email address

  • db – Session: Connect to the database

Returns:

A user object

async src.repository.users.get_user_by_email(email: str, db: Session) → User | None¶

The get_user_by_email function takes in an email and a database session, and returns the user associated with that email. If no such user exists, it returns None.

Parameters:

  • email – str: Specify the type of parameter that is expected to be passed into the function

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The first user that matches the email address passed in

async src.repository.users.save_new_password(user: User, password: str, db: Session) → None¶

The save_new_password function takes a user object, a password string, and the database session. It then sets the user’s password to be equal to the new password string. Finally it commits this change to the database.

Parameters:

  • user – User: Pass the user object to the function

  • password – str: Pass the new password to the function

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

None

async src.repository.users.update_avatar(email, url: str, db: Session) → User¶

The update_avatar function updates the avatar of a user.

Parameters:

  • email – Find the user in the database

  • url – str: Specify the type of data that is being passed into the function

  • db – Session: Pass in the database session

Returns:

The updated user object

async src.repository.users.update_token(user: User, token: str | None, db: Session) → None¶

The update_token function updates the refresh token for a user.

Parameters:

  • user – User: Identify the user in the database

  • token – str | None: Set the refresh_token field in the user table

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

Nothing, so the type is none

REST API routes Auth¶

async src.routes.auth.change_password(body: ChangePassword, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The change_password function is used to change the password of a user.

It takes in an email and password, which are used to verify that the user exists and has entered their current password correctly. If this is true, then it will hash the new_password provided by the user and save it as their new password.

Parameters:

  • body – ChangePassword: Get the email and password from the request body

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A message that the password has been changed

async src.routes.auth.confirmed_email(token: str, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The confirmed_email function is used to confirm a user’s email address.

It takes the token from the URL and uses it to get the user’s email address. The function then checks if there is a user with that email in our database, and if not, returns an error message. If there is a user with that email in our database, we check whether their account has already been confirmed or not. If it has been confirmed already, we return another error message saying so; otherwise we call repository_users’ confirmed_email function which sets the ‘confirmed’ field of that particular User object

Parameters:

  • token – str: Get the token from the url

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A message that the email has been confirmed

async src.routes.auth.login(body: OAuth2PasswordRequestForm = Depends(OAuth2PasswordRequestForm), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The login function is used to authenticate a user.

It takes the username and password from the request body, verifies them against the database, and returns an access token if successful.

Parameters:

  • body – OAuth2PasswordRequestForm: Validate the request body

  • db – Session: Get a database session

Returns:

A dict with the access_token, refresh_token and token type

async src.routes.auth.logout(credentials: HTTPAuthorizationCredentials = Security(HTTPBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The logout function is used to logout a user.

Parameters:

  • credentials – HTTPAuthorizationCredentials: Get the token from the request header

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

A http 204 status code

async src.routes.auth.refresh_token(credentials: HTTPAuthorizationCredentials = Security(HTTPBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The refresh_token function is used to refresh the access token.

The function takes in a refresh token and returns an access_token, a new refresh_token, and the type of token. If the user’s current refresh_token does not match what was passed into this function then it will return an error.

Parameters:

  • credentials – HTTPAuthorizationCredentials: Get the token from the request

  • db – Session: Get a database session

Returns:

A dictionary of the access_token, refresh_token and token type

async src.routes.auth.request_email(body: RequestEmail, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The request_email function is used to send an email to the user with a link that they can click on to confirm their email address. The function takes in a RequestEmail object, which contains the email of the user who wants to confirm their account. It then checks if there is already a confirmed user with that email address, and if so returns an error message saying as much. If not, it sends them an email containing a link they can click on.

Parameters:

  • body – RequestEmail: Get the email from the request body

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background queue

  • request – Request: Get the base_url of the request

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A message to the user

async src.routes.auth.reset_password(body: RequestEmail, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The reset_password function is used to reset a user’s password.

It takes in the email of the user and sends them an email with their new password. The function returns a message saying that an email has been sent.

Parameters:

  • body – RequestEmail: Get the email from the request

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Run the function in a separate thread

  • request – Request: Get the base url of the application

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A message that the new password has been sent to your email

async src.routes.auth.signup(body: UserModel, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The signup function creates a new user in the database.

It takes a UserModel object as input, which is validated by pydantic. The password is hashed using Argon2 and stored in the database. A background task sends an email to the user with their username.

Parameters:

  • body – UserModel: Validate the user data

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background tasks queue

  • request – Request: Get the base url of the server

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A UserModel object

REST API routes Clients¶

async src.routes.clients.create_users(body: ClientModel, db: Session = Depends(get_db), _: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The create_users function creates a new user in the database.

It takes an email, password, and phone number as input parameters. The function returns the newly created user object.

Parameters:

  • body – ClientModel: Get the data from the request body

  • db – Session: Get the database session

  • _ – User: Check if the user is logged in,

Returns:

A clientmodel object

async src.routes.clients.get_clients(limit: int = Query(10), offset: int = 0, db: Session = Depends(get_db), _: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The get_clients function returns a list of clients.

Parameters:

  • limit – int: Limit the number of clients returned

  • le – Limit the number of clients that can be returned at once

  • offset – int: Specify the number of records to skip before starting to return rows

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the repository layer

  • _ – User: Get the current user from the database

Returns:

A list of clients

async src.routes.clients.get_user(client_id: int = Path(Ellipsis), db: Session = Depends(get_db), _: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The get_user function is a GET request that returns the client with the given ID. The function requires an authenticated user and will return a 404 error if no client exists with the given ID.

Parameters:

  • client_id – int: Specify the client id that is passed in the url

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the repository function

  • _ – User: Get the current user from the auth_service

Returns:

A client object

async src.routes.clients.get_users_birthday(days: int = Query(7), db: Session = Depends(get_db), _: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The get_users_birthday function returns a list of users whose birthday is within the next x days.

Parameters:

  • days – int: Get the number of days from today to search for birthdays

  • le – Limit the number of days to 365

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

  • _ – User: Tell fastapi that we want to use the auth_service

Returns:

A list of users whose birthday is in the next x days

async src.routes.clients.remove_user(client_id: int = Path(Ellipsis), db: Session = Depends(get_db), _: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The remove_user function is used to remove a user from the database.

The function takes in an integer client_id, which is the id of the client that will be removed. It also takes in a Session object db, which represents our database session and allows us to interact with it. Finally, it takes in an optional User object _ (which we don’t use), but this parameter depends on another function called auth_service.get_current_user().

Parameters:

  • client_id – int: Specify the client to be removed

  • db – Session: Access the database

  • _ – User: Get the current user

Returns:

A client object

async src.routes.clients.search_clients(data: str, db: Session = Depends(get_db), _: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The search_clients function searches for clients in the database.
Args:

data (str): The search term to be used when searching for clients. db (Session, optional): SQLAlchemy Session. Defaults to Depends(get_db).

Parameters:

  • data – str: Search for a client by name or surname

  • db – Session: Get the database session

  • _ – User: Check if the user is logged in

Returns:

A list of clients

async src.routes.clients.update_user(body: ClientModel, client_id: int = Path(Ellipsis), db: Session = Depends(get_db), _: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The update_user function updates a user in the database.

The function takes an id, which is used to find the user in question, and a body of data that contains all of the information that will be updated. If no client with this id exists, then an HTTPException is raised.

Parameters:

  • body – ClientModel: Pass the client data to the function

  • client_id – int: Specify the id of the client to be deleted

  • db – Session: Get the database session

  • _ – User: Validate the user’s token

Returns:

The updated user object

REST API routes Users¶

async src.routes.users.read_users_me(current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The read_users_me function is a GET request that returns the current user’s information.

It requires authentication, and it uses the auth_service to get the current user.

Parameters:

current_user – User: Get the current user

Returns:

The current user, which is a user object

async src.routes.users.update_avatar_user(file: UploadFile = File(PydanticUndefined), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The update_avatar_user function updates the avatar of a user.

Parameters:

  • file – UploadFile: Get the file that is being uploaded

  • current_user – User: Get the current user

  • db – Session: Connect to the database

Returns:

The updated user

REST API service Auth¶

class src.services.auth.Auth¶

Bases: object

ALGORITHM = 'HS256'¶
SECRET_KEY = 'secret'¶
async create_access_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None)¶

The create_access_token function creates a new access token.

Parameters:

  • self – Refer to the current object

  • data – dict: Pass the data that will be encoded in the jwt token

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the expiration time of the access token

Returns:

A token that can be used to access the api

create_email_token(data: dict)¶

The create_email_token function takes a dictionary of data and returns a token. The token is created using the JWT library, which uses the SECRET_KEY and ALGORITHM to create an encoded string. The data dictionary contains information about the user’s email address, as well as when it was issued (iat) and when it expires (exp). The iat and exp values are added to the data dict before encoding.

Parameters:

  • self – Make the function a method of the class

  • data – dict: Pass in the data that will be encoded into the token

Returns:

A token that is encoded using the jwt library

async create_refresh_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None)¶

The create_refresh_token function creates a refresh token for the user.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • data – dict: Store the user’s id, username and email

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the expiration time for the refresh token

Returns:

A refresh token that is encoded with the user’s id, username and email

async decode_access_token(access_token: str)¶

The decode_access_token function takes an access token and decodes it using the SECRET_KEY. If the scope is ‘access_token’, then we return the email address of that user. If not, we raise a 401 error.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • access_token – str: Pass in the access token that is sent to the server

Returns:

The email of the user that was encoded in the access token

async decode_refresh_token(refresh_token: str)¶

The decode_refresh_token function is used to decode the refresh token. It takes a refresh_token as an argument and returns the email of the user if it’s valid. If not, it raises an HTTPException with status code 401 (UNAUTHORIZED) and detail ‘Could not validate credentials’.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • refresh_token – str: Pass the refresh token to the function

Returns:

The email of the user that is associated with the refresh token

async get_current_user(token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The get_current_user function is a dependency that will be used in the

protected endpoints. It takes a token as an argument and returns the user if it’s valid, otherwise raises an HTTPException with status code 401.

Parameters:

  • self – Access the class attributes and methods

  • token – str: Get the token from the request header

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A user object

async get_email_from_token(token: str)¶

The get_email_from_token function takes a token as an argument and returns the email address associated with that token. The function uses the jwt library to decode the token, which is then used to return the email address.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • token – str: Pass in the token that is sent to the user’s email

Returns:

The email address of the user who is logged in

get_password_hash(password: str)¶

The get_password_hash function takes a password as input and returns the hash of that password. The hash is generated using the pwd_context object, which is an instance of Flask-Bcrypt’s Bcrypt class.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • password – str: Get the password from the user

Returns:

A hash of the password

oauth2_scheme = <fastapi.security.oauth2.OAuth2PasswordBearer object>¶
pwd_context = <CryptContext>¶
r = Redis<ConnectionPool<Connection<host=localhost,port=6379,db=0>>>¶
verify_password(plain_password, hashed_password)¶

The verify_password function takes a plain-text password and hashed password as arguments. It then uses the pwd_context object to verify that the plain-text password matches the hashed one.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • plain_password – Pass in the password that is entered by the user

  • hashed_password – Compare the password that was hashed and stored in the database,

Returns:

A boolean value, true if the password is correct and false otherwise

REST API service Email¶

async src.services.email.send_email(email: EmailStr, username: str, host: str)¶

The send_email function sends an email to the user with a link that they can click on to verify their email address.

Parameters:

  • email – EmailStr: Specify the email address of the user

  • username – str: Personalize the email message

  • host – str: Pass the hostname of the server to the email template

Returns:

A coroutine object

async src.services.email.send_email_with_password(email: EmailStr, username: str, new_password: str, host: str)¶

The send_email_with_password function sends an email to the user with a new password.

Parameters:

  • email – EmailStr: Specify the email address of the user who requested a password reset

  • username – str: Pass the username of the user to be sent an email

  • new_password – str: Pass the new password to the email template

  • host – str: Pass the host url to the template

Returns:

A coroutine, which is a special object that can be used with asyncio

REST API service Generate Password¶

src.services.generate_password.generate_password()¶

The generate_password function generates a random password consisting of a letter, a digit, and a combination of letters and digits.

Returns:

A string of length 8

REST API service Roles¶

class src.services.roles.RolesAccess(allowed_roles: List[Role])¶

Bases: object

REST API service Upload Avatar¶

class src.services.upload_avatar.UploadService¶

Bases: object

static create_name_avatar(email: str, prefix: str)¶

The create_name_avatar function takes an email and a prefix, and returns a string of the form ‘prefix/name’. The name is the first 10 characters of the SHA256 hash of the email.

Parameters:

  • email – str: Specify the type of input that is expected

  • prefix – str: Specify the folder where the avatar will be saved

Returns:

A string

static get_url_avatar(public_id, version)¶
The get_url_avatar function takes in a public_id and version number,

then returns the url of the avatar image.

Parameters:

  • public_id – Identify the image in the cloudinary database

  • version – Get the latest version of an image

Returns:

A url to an image

static upload(file, public_id)¶

The upload function takes a file and public_id as arguments. It then uploads the file to Cloudinary using the public_id provided. The function returns a dictionary containing information about the uploaded image.

Parameters:

  • file – Specify the file to upload

  • public_id – Set the public id of the image

Returns:

A dictionary with the following fields
